awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Understanding how health information technology mediates collaborative reflection within care teams
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will develop cyber-human systems design principles grounded in empirical and user-centered methods to guide the development and implementation of health information technology systems that have a positive effect on team-based collaboration.  The delivery of healthcare services is changing in response to an increase in chronic conditions. Care is provided by teams often distributed across agencies, rather than by a single physician. The collaboration of a care team has also been extended to include active involvement of patients themselves, home caregivers, and community organizations. Integrating care that spans time, providers, and agencies is a growing challenge that exacerbates barriers to communication and collaboration. Despite its promise, health information technology (HIT) often fails to enhance distributed collaboration over time. Current methods and tools, including electronic health records, do not adequately support collaboration because they become passive information repositories, which do not inform distributed, collaborative reflection and decision-making for chronic care.  This research leverages prior work that (1) generated the framework of collaborative reflection, and (2) prototyped and piloted a novel HIT system named Lilypad, designed to support collaborative reflection within behavioral health.

The three aims of this research are: (1) to understand instances when the process of collaborative reflection breaks down and care advances without reliance on data or inclusion of multiple perspectives from across the care team, (2) to identify potential unintended consequences of HIT-mediated collaborative reflection, and (3) to generate empirically-based design principles for HIT that promotes collaborative reflection. Based on the promising results of exploratory studies, a long-term deployment study will investigate the use of the prototype across organizational boundaries. The first year will engage care teams in participatory design to tailor it for their needs and facilitate a transition to its use. Then, over two years of use, data will be triangulated from a range of methods, including: interviews to gather individual participant attitudes, observation of care team collaboration via use and non-use, and monitoring of usage logs. A sociotechnical study of Lilypad use will provide insight into how novel HIT systems can mediate collaborative reflection. In addition, this study will contribute to literature on unintended negative consequences of HIT use, and provide design and implementation guidelines for moderating these effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project ethnographically analyzed collaborative practices within behavioral care teams across clinical, school, and home care contexts, to understand how practices did and did not support the development of shared understanding about a child’s needs and care. This analysis allowed us to generate a conceptual framework that can guide design of health information technologies (HITs) toward shared understanding. We also provided a rich description of how care work and data work are experienced by clinicians in a behavioral health context.

Through a deployment of our novel HIT across multiple sites, we also unpacked how care teams collaborate on collecting and using behavioral data, with a focus on how data collection practices influence the quality of the resulting data, and for what types of activities these data need to be used. We then compared use of our system to broader use of available behavioral management technologies, and critically analyzed the adoption and implementation of these types of systems. We identified unintended consequences related to use of HITs exacerbating bias and contributing to a culture of surveillance, punishment, and control rather than care. We proposed the use of trauma theory and trauma-informed principles as a way to avoid such outcomes by appropriately framing behavior and interventions from the start of HIT conception and design. We also described caregiver (parent) experiences and information needs during the COVID-19 pandemic, outlining how HIT can be designed to support caregivers and care recipients when they navigate significant life changes.

A key finding in this work has been the importance of interpersonal relationships across the care team. That is, no amount of data, or design of tools for collaboratively reflecting on data, seem to support care if there is not an existing foundation of relationships. These relationships include caregiver-child, teacher-child, teacher-parent, parent-clinician, etc. We have found that such interpersonal relationships are critical to reflecting on health data collaboratively, building trust, collaborating effectively, etc. Therefore, the design of systems should focus on supporting interpersonal relationships and the meaningful communication and social connection that enables relationships to be formed and maintained over time - rather than data sharing or visualization alone. By shifting from a focus on behavioral data to interpersonal relationships, we identified attachment theory as an important theoretical framework that exemplifies how systems can be designed to support relationships rather than behavior. We consequently introduced and described the approach of attachment-informed design of systems for behavioral and mental health.
